diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones. Can cause constipation, cognitive issues (including word-finding difficulty), and attention deficit.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, and your body doesn't have enough water and other fluids to carry out its normal functions. Can contribute to constipation and cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia — a condition in which blood lacks adequate healthy red blood cells. Anemia can cause cognitive issues, including difficulty with attention and word-finding.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). Diabetes can cause vascular anomalies and might contribute to attention deficit issues.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can have systemic effects, including vascular anomalies and cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include cognitive impairments such as word-finding difficulty and attention deficits.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by dryness of the mouth and eyes. It can also cause systemic issues such as vascular anomalies and cognitive symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's Disease
diagnoses.description: A progressive nervous system disorder that affects movement. Symptoms can include cognitive issues such as word-finding difficulty and attention deficit.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinuses that persists for a long time or keeps coming back. It can lead to post-nasal drip and potentially contribute to word-finding difficulty due to associated cognitive strain.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This condition can result in neurological issues, including cognitive and attention deficits, as well as constipation.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes, and fevers. Dry eyes and lymphadenopathy can also be associated with this condition.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the body's immune system attacking its own cells and tissues, particularly affecting the tear and saliva glands, leading to dry eyes and dry mouth. Systemic symptoms can include lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow. Leukocytosis (high white blood cell count) is a common symptom along with fatigue, fever, and swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy).

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer originating from white blood cells (lymphocytes). Symptoms include persistent fatigue, night sweats, unexplained weight loss, fever, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A cancer that develops in the lymphatic system. It differs from Hodgkin's Lymphoma in the specific type of lymphocyte affected. Symptoms are similar, including lymphadenopathy, fever, and night sweats.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Commonly known as mono, this viral infection can cause fever, sore throat, swollen lymph glands (lymphadenopathy), and fatigue. It can sometimes lead to an increase in white blood cell count (leukocytosis).

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which the body cannot properly regulate the number of immune system cells (lymphocytes). This condition leads to lymphadenopathy, an enlarged spleen, and sometimes leukocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Castleman Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder involving an overgrowth of cells in the body's lymphatic system. It can manifest through symptoms such as lymphadenopathy, weight loss, fever, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the growth of tiny collections of granulomas in different parts of the body, commonly affecting the lungs and lymph nodes. Symptoms may include lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and eye dryness.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. While joint symptoms are most common, the disease can also cause dry eyes and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially causing hypoglycemia, irritability, and goiter which might be associated with angioedema in rare cases.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause symptoms like irritability and seizure disorders, with other neurological symptoms such as tinnitus being possible.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing recurring episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). It can occasionally affect the face and throat, which might lead to life-threatening conditions, along with other varied symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Type 1 Diabetes
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition in which the pancreas produces little or no insulin, leading to hypoglycemia, which can cause irritability and might also be associated indirectly with seizure disorders due to severe cases of hypoglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that can lead to dizzy spells (vertigo) and hearing loss. In some cases, tinnitus can be a primary symptom, and vertigo might contribute to falls, potentially causing seizures in severe circumstances.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemic disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions causing hypoglycemia that can lead to symptoms such as seizure disorders due to low blood sugar, irritability, and other related symptoms depending on the underlying cause.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system (neurological) disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. People with epilepsy might experience irritability and tinnitus as additional symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Insulinoma
diagnoses.description: A small tumor in the pancreas that produces an excess amount of insulin, leading to hypoglycemia. Symptoms can include irritability, seizures, and hypoglycemia itself.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when the adrenal glands do not produce enough of their hormones, leading to symptoms such as irritability, hypoglycemia, and less commonly, seizure disorders.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin and other parts of the body, which can cause symptoms such as tinnitus, irritability, and in some cases, angioedema.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects circulation (blood flow) and involves a significant increase in heart rate upon standing.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder that affects connective tissues, supporting skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It's often associated with POTS, as well as various skin manifestations including cysts.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by a proliferation of mast cells or an abnormal release of these cells' mediators, potentially leading to symptoms like angioedema and migratory pruritus.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body. It can be associated with fatigue, sleep problems, memory issues, and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can lead to fatigue, pain, balance and coordination issues, and cognitive problems.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by extreme fatigue or tiredness that doesn't go away with rest and can't be explained by an underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body, often with various dermatological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder causing severe swelling in various parts of the body, notably the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway.

diagnoses.name: Hypermobility Spectrum Disorders (HSD)
diagnoses.description: A group of conditions related to joint hypermobility (joints that stretch further than normal), associated with a range of symptoms including potential skin issues and POTS.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age, associated with a number of cysts on the ovaries. While not directly linked to POTS, it shares some common symptoms including fatigue.

diagnoses: Eating Disorder (e.g., Anorexia Nervosa, Bulimia Nervosa)
Heart Conditions (e.g., Arrhythmias, Congenital Heart Disease)

diagnoses.name: Myeloproliferative disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that affect blood cell production in the bone marrow, potentially causing basophilia, easy bruising due to platelet dysfunction, and anemia which may contribute to hypoferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 or Folate deficiency
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in these nutrients can lead to anemia, causing symptoms like easy bruising and hypoferritinemia, as well as neurological symptoms affecting vision.

diagnoses.name: Iron deficiency anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that leads to insufficient iron levels (hypoferritinemia), causing symptoms like chest pain and difficulty focusing vision due to reduced oxygen supply.

diagnoses.name: Hemophilia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that impairs the blood's ability to clot, leading to easy bruising and, in severe cases, internal bleeding that could manifest as chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow with excessive production of abnormal white blood cells, leading to symptoms such as basophilia, chest pain, and easy bruising.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by deficiency in or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor, leading to symptoms like easy bruising. It does not directly cause hypoferritinemia but may be related to chronic blood loss.

diagnoses.name: Chronic myeloid leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of leukemia characterized by increased and unregulated growth of predominantly myeloid cells in the bone marrow and the accumulation of these cells in the blood, leading to symptoms such as basophilia and easy bruising.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Although not a direct cause, hypothyroidism can lead to symptoms like difficulty focusing vision due to myxedema, and can indirectly affect the body's ability to absorb iron, possibly leading to hypoferritinemia.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that leads to the overproduction of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Basophilia is a common finding, and while easy bruising is less common, it can occur due to qualitative platelet defects.

diagnoses.name: Anemia of chronic disease
diagnoses.description: A condition arising from chronic infections, inflammatory diseases, or malignancies that can lead to hypoferritinemia and present symptoms such as easy bruising and chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: A temporary heart condition that often results from stress and presents similarly to a heart attack, with symptoms such as chest pain and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to various body parts including the joints, skin, kidneys, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and brain. It can present with a wide range of symptoms, including lymphadenopathy and aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, leading to abnormalities such as aneurysms (especially aortic aneurysms), tall stature, and long limbs. It can also affect the heart and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness, and coughing.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disease that causes vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels), leading to symptoms such as asthma, wheezing, and possibly aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener's)
diagnoses.description: A form of vasculitis that can affect the nose, lungs, kidneys, and other organs. Symptoms may include sinusitis, dyspnea (breathing difficulties), and renal problems.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting many parts of the body. The most common symptoms include mouth sores, genital sores, eye inflammation, and skin rashes. Can lead to vascular problems like aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Loeys-Dietz Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder similar to Marfan Syndrome that affects the connective tissue in the body. It is characterized by widely spaced eyes, a split uvula, vascular abnormalities including aneurysms, and skeletal issues.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases that cause the skin and connective tissues to harden and tighten. May also affect internal organs and can lead to difficulties swallowing (dysphagia) and problems with the heart and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs, characterized by breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (including Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Angioedema (not otherwise specified, could be hereditary or acquired)
Mast cell disorders (including Mastocytosis and Mast Cell Activation Syndrome)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) Acute Exacerbation
Heart Failure with Acute Pulmonary Edema
Mastocytosis (including Systemic Mastocytosis and Cutaneous Mastocytosis)
Anaphylactic Shock due to unknown substance

diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of symptoms including dysphagia, headache, and parasthesia.
Migraines that are preceded by a sensory disturbance, known as an aura, which can include visual phenomena (scintillation), sensory changes, or speech or language issues.
A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain that can cause hearing loss and sometimes headache or dysphagia if large enough.
A medical condition where the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, causing symptoms such as headache, dysphagia, and parasthesia.
Abnormal growths within the brain that can cause a variety of symptoms depending on their location and size, including headache, dysphagia, hearing loss, and scintillation.
A rare, progressive neurological disorder affecting multiple systems of the body, including the ability to swallow (dysphagia), balance, and sensory functions leading to symptoms such as parasthesia.
A disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord, leading to muscle weakness, dysphagia, and eventually severe disability.
A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which can lead to dysphagia and may be associated with other symptoms.
A form of syphilis that affects the nervous system, potentially leading to headache, hearing loss, and neurological symptoms such as parasthesia.

An inflammatory disease affecting large and medium-sized arteries, which can lead to headache, jaw pain during eating (which can be confused with dysphagia), and in severe cases, can cause vision problems or stroke-like symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves neurological phenomena (aura) like visual disturbances (scotomas, flashing lights) before the actual migraine headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms such as paralysis or loss of muscle movement, problems speaking or seeing, etc.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to the brain, causing sudden, short-term symptoms similar to those of a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and even paralysis.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes, leading to numbness, pain, and weakness in the hands, feet, and other parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to neurological issues, causing symptoms like tingling, muscle weakness, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that causes muscle weakness and fatigue, which can worsen with activity and improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Neurological symptoms can occur in the later stages of the disease, including paralysis and neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Any intracranial tumor caused by an abnormal and uncontrolled cell division, either in the brain itself, in the cranial nerves, in the brain envelopes, skull, pituitary and pineal gland. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, problems with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.

diagnoses: Infectious causes (e.g., streptococcal infections, hepatitis B associated)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Cancer (various types, depending on specific findings)
Hepatitis B and C with cryoglobulinemia
Schizophrenia (in rare cases, can present with physical symptoms)
